author: MaDeLapHnT

text:
Andy's pronunciation is comprehensible enough. I think many of us (native Japanese) find it too harsh for the girl to point it out as wrong. It just sounds a little bit foreign, that's all.
Japanese words/phrases don't have stress accents like English, but pitch accents, which are not always crucial (as in Chinese). The native tone/pitch of OYASUMINASAI  is like (_¯¯¯¯¯¯) syllabically with no stress and the vowel U is highly reduced  as the Japanese girls in the video show.﻿

author: LifeOfBrian

text: He made a very minor mistake but it's not like you can't tell what he's saying. Spelling in Romanji, "good night" in Japanese is "Oyasumi" or "Oyasuminasai." Breaking it apart, it is pronounced O-Ya-Su-Mi-Na-Sa-I. What Andy pronounced was O-Ya-Su-Min-Na-Sai. When he got to the "Mi" and "Na" he said "Min" and "Na." It can't be helped that he pronounced it like that. It's like an American accent. Like in American English, "hate" is pronounced as Heit while in Romanji it is pronounced as Ha-Te﻿
author: Tong Pa Fu

text: +Tong Pa Fu - okay, I see what you mean. It's a subtle difference - more separated syllables, like "sa" (sah, in English) and "i" (ee, in English) - do you enen need to say the full "oyasuminasai", or is "oyasumi" just a shorter, more informal version? Thanks, just trying to learn.﻿
author: LifeOfBrian

text: +LifeOfBrian - *even﻿
author: LifeOfBrian

text: You can just use Oyasumi but that's the informal use of it. It's like saying "Night" and not "Good Night."﻿

author: Jane Tris

text:
What I don't understand is that she said it exactly the way her first friend did; smooth rhythm and a more or less flat intonation. This is perfectly acceptable in Japanese because there is not a lot of stressed syllables (one can make an argument with regards to っ). In English, rhythm and tone are mostly predetermined, but not vowel sounds. Japanese is the opposite, so I think their idea of 'correct pronunciation' is off. So many bigots rushing to their idol's defense.

I've been immersed in the language for nearly 6 years, and I'm quite familiar with the pronunciation of common phrases by a variety of native speakers. But whatever. On the internet, everyone's an expert.﻿

text: Oh god, it's basic Japanese, something you can find in any elementary Japanese textbook. I'm a half Japanese half white person and I couldn't give a shit how someone pronounces oyasuminasai because I admire their attempt at speaking the language. She should leave it to someone who's completely Japanese and grew up in Japanese culture to butcher peoples pronunciations. I get it you appreciate the culture but you're not Japanese and you're not doing the culture any favors being an elitist, don't try to speak for them.﻿
author: Shogo Yamada

text:
+Shogo Yamada You're totally right. It is basic Japanese. I would like to thank you for pointing that out. :)
You know what? I think you're right when you stated that I should leave it to someone who is completely Japanese and grew up in Japan and the culture to butcher peoples' pronunciations: and that's exactly what I did. That's why I had my Japanese coworker's help me out. I think they did a really great job!

I'm sorry you feel that I'm trying to be Japanese and I'm sorry that you think--or thought--that I was doing things out of... some reason for the Japanese culture. It was a fun video I made with my coworkers and friends. They had fun making it and they all laughed and were able to appear on an American national TV show. I wouldn't rescind that for the world just because you, or many a few other people, think that I'm attempting to be an elitist. It was a fun joke and I'm glad that Conan saw that, took that, and ran with it. :)

Thanks for the ride, Conan!﻿

author: Kalasbyxan

text:
+Isaakmedextraa
It's more like Andy used an American pronunciation for the "uh" sound. It sounded more like "oyasuhma nasai" than how Japanese people say it. Since the word is "oyasumi nasai" the u in "oyasumi" is pronounced since it isn't like the "u" at the end of a verb at the end of a verb (desu, ~masu, etc). There are some exceptions to that rule, but yeah.

Andy's pronunciation wasn't that bad, but it was a fun opportunity for myself and my coworkers.﻿
